channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Maldives’ Transition to Democracy Appears Increasingly Precarious
item.description: Diplomats say President Abdulla Yameen is becoming more autocratic and unpredictable, citing the influence of gangs and the imprisonment of a former president.
item.dc:creator: GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: The Maldivian police scuffled with Mohamed Nasheed, the former president, in February after he arrived at a courthouse in the capital, Male, for a bail hearing on terrorism charges.

item.title: Lens Blog: The Evidence of Mexico’s Missing
item.description: After 43 students disappeared in Mexico, Christopher Gregory went there to document the traces left by countless others who have been killed or kidnapped.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ
item.media:description: A team of family members combing the mountains near Cocula, near Iguala, Mexico, after receiving an anonymous tip that there had been cartel activity in the area.

item.title: Israel’s Military Faces Delicate Balance in West Bank
item.description: Though the Palestinian Authority leadership was threatening to scale back its security coordination with Israel, both sides appear to have an interest in preventing an outbreak of violence.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers searching in June for three missing teenagers near Hebron, West Bank. The youths were kidnapped and killed by a squad affiliated with Hamas.

item.title: Israel Suggests Ways to Make Iran Nuclear Deal ‘More Reasonable’
item.description: The government listed its desired changes to a preliminary agreement reached between Tehran and world powers including Washington.
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Yuval Steinitz, Israel’s minister of intelligence and strategic affairs, in Paris last month.

item.title: Turkey Blocks Twitter, YouTube and Sites That Published Hostage Photo
item.description: Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu called outlets that circulated the photograph of a prosecutor taken hostage and later killed “tools of terrorist propaganda.”
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:description: A photograph circulated on social media showing Mehmet Selim Kiraz, the prosecutor taken hostage and killed in Istanbul on Tuesday.

item.title: Letter From Europe: France Lets U.S. Lead in Corruption Fight
item.description: In 15 years, not a single company has been convicted in France of paying bribes overseas, which has left prosecutions to other countries.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Ancient Chinese Community Celebrates Its Jewish Roots, and Passover
item.description: The Jewish population of Kaifeng has witnessed a surprising revival in recent years, a phenomenon all the more notable for the tolerant eye that the Chinese government, which does not count Judaism among state-sanctioned religions, seems to have turned toward it.
item.dc:creator: BECKY DAVIS
item.media:description: Barnaby Yeh of the Sino-Judaic Institute leads morning prayers for Jewish descendants in Kaifeng.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Ha Jin on Patriotism, Exile and ‘A Map of Betrayal’
item.description: In his latest novel, Ha Jin explores the quandary of a Chinese spy in the United States who, like the author himself, cannot return to his homeland.
item.dc:creator: YONGXI WU

item.title: Kenyan Fighter Jets Bomb Shabab Training Camps in Somalia
item.description: President Uhuru Kenyatta had vowed to respond “in the severest way possible” to a massacre at a university last week that killed nearly 150 students.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: Israel’s Military Faces Delicate Balance in West Bank
item.description: Though the Palestinian Authority leadership was threatening to scale back its security coordination with Israel, both sides appear to have an interest in preventing an outbreak of violence.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers searching in June for three missing teenagers near Hebron, West Bank. The youths were kidnapped and killed by a squad affiliated with Hamas.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: What Vietnam Must Now Do
item.description: Joining the Trans-Pacific Partnership would help the country develop and liberalize, and fend off China's ambitions in Asia.
item.dc:creator: TUONG LAI

item.title: Shiite Rebels in Yemen Seize Scores of Rival Sunnis
item.description: The Islah party said two of its leaders were among 120 members arrested.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Bulgaria Puts Up a New Wall, but This One Keeps People Out
item.description: The former Communist nation has completed 20 miles of fence along its border with Turkey, and plans to extend it to 100 miles, to stem the flow of refugees.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: India Tries Evacuating Citizens in Yemen
item.description: About 2,000 Indians have been transported out of Yemen, but the deteriorating conditions there mean that no more evacuations from Aden will be possible.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR and ELLEN BARRY

item.title: One of Libya’s Rival Governments Moves to Control Oil Revenue
item.description: One of the two factions battling for control of Libya took steps to divert incoming oil revenue away from the Central Bank and into its own account in the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Istanbul Journal: Old Haunt of U.S. Spies Becomes a Playground for Istanbul’s Elite
item.description: The United States has become the landlord to the private club empire Soho House, as part of a deal initially intended to keep a historic building as a space to foster relations with the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Tara Todras-Whitehill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The mansion that once served as the United States Consulate in Istanbul has been reborn as an outpost of Soho House, a network of clubs across Europe and North America.

item.title: Shiite Rebels in Yemen Seize Scores of Rival Sunnis
item.description: The Islah party said two of its leaders were among 120 members arrested.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Pakistani Man Killed 10 Relatives, Police Say
item.description: Police officials say a dispute over a delayed marriage led the man to kill his uncle, aunt, four male cousins and four female cousins, including the woman he wanted to marry,
item.dc:creator: SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: One Woman’s Mission to Free Laos From Millions of Unexploded Bombs
item.description: Channapha Khamvongsa has led a single-minded effort to clean up the fallout of a nine-year American air campaign that made Laos one of the most heavily bombed places on earth.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS FULLER
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Channapha Khamvongsa has led a single-minded effort to rid Laos of the live ordnance still buried here, the legacy of a nine-year American air campaign.

item.title: President Obama Calls Preliminary Iran Nuclear Deal ‘Our Best Bet’
item.description: In an interview, President Obama called last week’s preliminary agreement a “once in a lifetime opportunity” to curb the spread of nuclear weapons in a dangerous region while reassuring critics.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER
item.media:description: President Obama in an interview Saturday at the White House. The president emphasized to Israel that “we’ve got their backs.”
